block.p: To Pursue Missile Project, U.S. Offers Russia a Deal The Bush administration is offering Russia incentives to drop its opposition to American missile defense sites in Poland and the Czech Republic, including an invitation to begin linking some American and Russian antimissile systems, according to senior administration officials.

U.S. Building Wall in Iraq American military commanders in Baghdad, in an effort to quell the widening sectarian violence in the city, are building a 12-foot-high, three-mile-long wall separating a historic Sunni enclave from Shiite neighborhoods.

Mayor's Death Disturbs Japan The shooting death this week of Nagasaki's popular mayor has left people puzzling over the killer's motive and has set off a national outcry about the city's teeming criminal underworld.

Fears Before Nigerian Vote An opposition party claimed that soldiers in Nigeria had seized ballots that had already been filled out in favor of the governing party's presidential candidate, raising fears of irregularities in today's election.

Indian Nuclear Deal in Jeopardy A nuclear accord hailed as the centerpiece of India's new friendship with the United States appears in jeopardy, as Indian politicians argue about whether its limitations on their nuclear activities offend the country's sense of sovereignty.

Law Should Have Barred Weapon Sales to Gunman Under federal law, the Virginia Tech gunman, Seung-Hui Cho, should have been prohibited from buying a gun after a state court declared him to be a danger to himself and others in late 2005 and sent him for psychiatric treatment, a government official and several legal experts said.
Many of the 32 victims of the shooting rampage at Virginia Tech were remembered at memorial services around the state and the nation, at the same time as the family of their killer issued an apology.

Taming Wildfires in Georgia Hundreds of firefighters from across the Southeast placed themselves between homes and wildfires in South Georgia, trying to fend off blazes that have blackened 42,000 acres, destroyed 20 homes, and forced hundreds of residents to evacuate.

Tax Break Spurs Donations A tax break, part of a relief package to aid victims of Hurricane Katrina, spurred $11 billion in donations to charity, the Treasury Department estimates, more than triple what was originally projected.

Reading Program Under Fire The federal Education Department's inspector general has asked the Justice Department to investigate Reading First, the Bush administration's $6 billion program to teach poor children to read by third grade.

Congestion-Pricing Plan Faces Barriers and Delays A plan to charge drivers to bring their vehicles into the busiest parts of Manhattan, which Mayor Bloomberg is expected to propose tomorrow, faces daunting obstacles and is likely to be years away, both supporters and opponents of the idea said.

Corzine Breathing on His Own Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey was breathing fully on his own for the first time in a week after doctors removed a ventilator that had been helping him breathe since he sustained catastrophic injuries in a car accident last week. B1

New Check on Co-op Boards? Nearly two-thirds of the members of the New York City Council are co-sponsoring a measure to shed light on the shadowy process by which co-op boards decide which apartment buyers to accept and which to reject. The bill would force co-op boards to give reasons for rejecting an applicant. A1

Nigerian Oil Production A surge of violence in the Niger Delta, the epicenter of Nigeria's petroleum industry, has contributed to higher oil prices and tighter supplies. This instability is likely to be one of the thorniest political problems for the country's new president.
